item.title: Key Management Glossary
item.description:
Term Definition
Symmetric-key algorithm A cryptographic algorithm that uses the same secret key for an operation and its complement (e.g., encryption and decryption). Also called a secret-key algorithm.
Symmetric key A single cryptographic key that is used with a symmetric-key cryptographic algorithm, is uniquely associated with one or more entities, and is not made public (i.e., the key is kept secret). A symmetric key is often called a secret key. See Secret key.
Secret key A single cryptographic key that is used with a symmetric-key cryptographic algorithm, is uniquely associated with one or more entities and is not made public (i.e., the key is kept secret). A secret key is also called a Symmetric key.
The use of the term “secret” in this context does not imply a classification level but rather implies the need to protect the key from disclosure.
Public-key（asymmetric）cryptographic algorithm A cryptographic algorithm that uses two related keys: a public key and a private key. The two keys have the property that determining the private key from the public key is computationally infeasible.
Asymmetric key algorithm See Public-key cryptographic algorithm.
Key pair A public key and its corresponding private key; a key pair is used with a public-key algorithm.
Public key A cryptographic key used with a public-key cryptographic algorithm that is uniquely associated with an entity and that may be made public. In an asymmetric-key (public-key) cryptosystem, the public key has a corresponding private key. The public key may be known by anyone and, depending on the algorithm, may be used, for example, to:
1. Verify a digital signature that was generated using the corresponding private key,
2. Encrypt keys that can be decrypted using the corresponding private key, or
3. Compute a shared secret during a key-agreement transaction.
Private key A cryptographic key used with a public-key cryptographic algorithm that is uniquely associated with an entity and is not made public. In an asymmetric-key (public-key) cryptosystem, the private key has a corresponding public key. Depending on the algorithm, the private key may be used, for example, to:
1. Compute the corresponding public key,
2. Compute a digital signature that may be verified by the corresponding public key,
3. Decrypt keys that were encrypted by the corresponding public key, or
4. Compute a shared secret during a key-agreement transaction.

Reference
NIST SP 800-57 Part 1 Rev.5 [PDF]

item.title: Vehicle Cyber Security
item.description:
UN Regulation (WIP)

UNECE WP.29 GRVA 6th session Informal documents

  • GRVA-06-19-Rev.1
    Proposal for a new UN Regulation on Cyber security
    [PDF]

UNECE WP.29 GRVA 2020 Working Documents

  • ECE/TRANS/WP.29/GRVA/2020/2
    Proposal for a new UN Regulation on uniform provisions concerning the approval of vehicles with regard to cyber security and of their cybersecurity management systems
    [PDF]

  • ECE/TRANS/WP.29/GRVA/2020/3
    Proposal for the 01 series of amendments to the new UN Regulation on uniform provisions concerning the approval of vehicles with regard to cyber security and of cybersecurity management systems
    [PDF]

Standard (WIP)

  • ISO/SAE DIS 21434
    Road vehicles — Cybersecurity engineering [Web]

Standard

  • SAE J3061
    Cybersecurity Guidebook for Cyber-Physical Vehicle Systems [Web]
  • SAE J3101
    Hardware Protected Security for Ground Vehicles [Web]

item.title: Apollo Dreamview
item.description:
Dreamview is a visualization tool for Baidu Apollo (Open Software Platform).

Dreamview is a web application that,

  1. visualizes the current output of relevant autonomous driving modules, e.g. planning trajectory, car localization, chassis status, etc.
  2. provides human-machine interface for users to view hardware status, turn on/off of modules, and start the autonomous driving car.
  3. provides debugging tools, such as PnC Monitor to efficiently track module issues.

Usage of Dreamview, see Dreamview Usage Table.

As described in DreamView FAQs, it can be used “Sim Control” to confirm the planning trajectory.

Turn on the “PNC Monitor” from the “Others” panel, you should be able to view the Planning, Control, Latency graphs as the header image.

item.title: CARLA
item.description:
CARLA is an open-source simulator for autonomous driving research developed by Computer Vision Center (CVC) at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona.

The software is available on GitHub, the documentation is available on Read the Docs.

Epic Games’s Unreal Engine 4 is used as a game engine.

It currently has integration with Autoware Fundation’s Autoware.AI using ROS bridge for CARLA simulator.

item.title: LGSVL Simulator
item.description:
LGSVL Simulator is an autonomous vehicle simulator developed by LG Electronics Silicon Valley Lab (LGSVL).

The software is available on GitHub, the documentation is available on Web.

Unity Technologies’s Unity is used as a game engine.

It currently has integration with Baidu’s Apollo (LGSVL fork) and Autoware Fundation’s Autoware.

item.title: Autoware
item.description:
Autoware is an autonomous driving software developed by Autoware Fundation.

There are three projects: Autoware.AI, Autoware.IO, and Autoware.Auto.

Autoware.AI built on ROS 1 is available on Gitlab, Autoware.Auto built on ROS 2 is also available on Gitlab.

item.title: Apollo
item.description:
Apollo is an open autonomous driving platform developed by Baidu.

The open software platform is available on Github.

The latest release is Apollo 5.5.

The latest release tag is apollo-v5.5.0. In addition to the tag, there is r5.5.0 branch. The branch continues to make changes for Apollo 5.5.

Apollo 3.5 and later, instead of the Apollo ROS, has been used Apollo Cyber RT.

Caffe is used as a deep learning framework for the perception module. Since Apollo 5.0, Baidu’s PaddlePaddle (PArallel Distributed Deep LEarning) is also supported.

item.title: Baidu Apollo Documentation Project
item.description:
Documented using Doxygen from the code comment of Apollo v5.5.0 Perception Module published by Baidu on GitHub.
